raw_comment:
One of the things that I noticed from this graph was that the greater the income the more chances for admissions acceptance on elite colleges. For the average admissions rate without legacy status is lower than the ones that have legacy on those colleges.  The people who have a legacy or relative who attended these colleges have 7 chances ahead of the students without relatives who attended these colleges before them.  I wonder why the students who have relatives at those colleges have better chances than the people who are going to their colleges for the first time. And why does the parent's income also impact their admissions? 
This graph can be a good example of how college acceptance can impact the college's applications of the High Schools that don't have the right income or families on colleges.  
Does income influence college acceptance?
ace_sentences: I noticed something from this graph.
If income is greater then the chance of admission acceptance at an elite college is greater.
The average admission rate without legacy status is lower than the average admission rate with legacy status at these colleges.
A student who has a legacy has 7 chances more than a student who does not have a legacy.
A student who has a relative who attended such a college has a better chance than a student who does not have such a relative.
I wonder why a student who has a relative at such a college has a better chance.
I wonder why a parent's income impacts admission.
College acceptance can impact the applications to a college from a high school.
Some high schools do not have the right income.
Some high schools do not have families at colleges.
I ask whether income influences college acceptance.
